awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building Cybersecurity Capacity in Pervasive Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to build cybersecurity capacity of the United States in pervasive computing. Although significant efforts have been made in addressing the security and privacy issues of pervasive computing in research community, a strategic implementation that promotes workforce development from both academic and experiential learning in cybersecurity education is still lacking in pervasive computing. It is imperative to bring cybersecurity research results into education, cultivate the well prepared cybersecurity workforce, and strengthen the long-term collaboration among academic institutions, industry, and government. 

The project identifies five major objectives in security and privacy issues of pervasive computing: 1) developing new courses and course modules; 2) constructing hands-on virtual labs; 3) engaging students in research with timely research topics; 4) establishing and strengthening relationships with partners; and 5) developing career interest and professional capabilities in cybersecurity with a focus on women and underrepresented students. Unified under the central theme of security and privacy, the wide coverage of cyberspace facets in pervasive computing will allow students to learn the state-of-the-art research findings, gain hands-on experiences from the most up-to-date software, platforms, and infrastructures, engage in scientific research in their best interests, and obtain a comprehensive in-breadth appreciation of the overall cybersecurity state-of-the-art through the new courses and labs, industry-sponsored capstones, cooperative research projects, cybersecurity student organizations, invited talks, and webinars held by the proposed project.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project are to provide comprehensive coverage of cybersecurity education, create the well-prepared cybersecurity workforce, and strengthen the long-term collaboration with industry, government, and other academic institutions in cybersecurity with pervasive computing in general, and cloud computing, software-defined networking, mobile computing, vehicular ad-hoc networks, cyber-physical system, and digital forensics in particular.

The project has been successfully implemented at Oakland University and beyond. Some detailed outcomes are listed below:

  1. We have developed and matured courses modules for four (4) proposed courses. The developed course modules have been integrated into three (3) undergraduate-level courses and three (3) graduate-level courses at Oakland University (OU), from which over five hundred and twenty (520+) students (460+ students from OU and 60+ students from California State University Sacramento) have received the training. The course modules and the hands-on practices are well received by our students. The curriculum and hands-on labs have been shared with three (3) institutions nationwide.
  2. We have applied ReScuE (The Range for Security Education), a cloud-based system dedicated to cybersecurity hands-on labs, to undergraduate and graduate courses. A total number of seven (7) cybersecurity-related hands-on labs, which correspond to ReScuE and our proposed objectives, have been matured and disseminated by one (1) dedicated website and one (1) YouTube channel.
  3. We have evaluated the learning outcomes of the ReScuE curriculum and hands-on labs several times during the supporting period. The pedagogic research has been published at various venues. The educational research about the long-term and extensive impact of ReScuE is in preparation. We confirm that ReScuE can achieve most of the technical and security features we have promised in both key timing points. In addition, we demonstrate that ReScuE can gain the technical and security advantages we have proposed and improve the educational learning outcome for the students at different institutions.
  4. We have published a total number of nineteen (19) research manuscripts during the supporting period, including one (1) book chapter, five (5) journal papers, nine (9) conference papers, four (4) posters. We have presented ReScuE and strengthened the partnerships among academic institutions, industry, and government, reported the status of this sponsored project, and/or acknowledged the generous sponsorship of the NSF in over thirty-six (36) venues.
  5. We have successfully engaged around ten (10) Ph.D. students, eight (8) master's students, twenty (20) undergraduate students, and one (1) high school student during the supporting period.
  6. We have provided professional training, lectures, seminars, guided competition, research opportunities to more than ten (10) female and underrepresented minority students.
  7. Ten (10) female and underrepresented minority students have engaged in the research projects relevant to the ReScuE project.
  8. We have given lectures and training to ten (10) REU student participants (2017) and twenty-four (24) GenCyber teacher participants (2018).
  9. At OU, the System Administration Track of the BS program in Information Technology has been designated as the National Centers of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) in 2018. The sponsored project has benefited most students of the IT major since 2018 at OU. The PI and other faculty have proposed a new B.S. program of cybersecurity in Fall 2021 and are ready to be reviewed by the School of Engineering in Spring 2022.
  10. We have led students to participate in cybersecurity-related challenges and competitions, including the Oakland University Hackathon (Grizzhacks 2018), CyberTruck Challenge (2018 and 2021), the 2021 ISACA Detroit Chapter 8th Annual Scholarship Competition(the 2nd place), and the 2021 MobilityForward AI Mini Challenge (the 1st place). The winners of both competitions involve female students.

Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Anyi Liu

The major goals of this project are to provide comprehensive coverage of cybersecurity education, create the well-prepared cybersecurity workforce, and strengthen the long-term collaboration with industry, government, and other academic institutions in cybersecurity with pervasive computing in general, and cloud computing, software-defined networking, mobile computing, vehicular ad-hoc networks, cyber-physical system, and digital forensics in particular.

The project has been successfully implemented at Oakland University and beyond. Some detailed outcomes are listed below:

We      have developed and matured courses modules for four (4) proposed      courses. The developed course modules have been integrated into three      (3) undergraduate-level courses and three (3) graduate-level      courses at Oakland University (OU), from which over five hundred and      twenty (520+) students (460+ students from OU and 60+      students from California State University Sacramento) have received      the training. The course modules and the hands-on practices are well      received by our students. The curriculum and hands-on labs have been      shared with three (3) institutions nationwide.
We      have applied ReScuE (The Range for Security      Education), a cloud-based system dedicated to cybersecurity      hands-on labs, to undergraduate and graduate courses. A total number of seven      (7) cybersecurity-related hands-on labs, which correspond to ReScuE      and our proposed objectives, have been matured and disseminated by one      (1) dedicated website and one (1) YouTube channel.
We      have evaluated the learning outcomes of the ReScuE curriculum and hands-on      labs several times during the supporting period. The pedagogic      research has been published at various venues. The educational research about      the long-term and extensive impact of ReScuE is in preparation. We confirm      that ReScuE can achieve most of the technical and security features we      have promised in both key timing points. In addition, we demonstrate that      ReScuE can gain the technical and security advantages we have proposed and      improve the educational learning outcome for the students at different      institutions.
We      have published a total number of nineteen (19) research manuscripts during the supporting period, including one (1) book chapter, five      (5) journal papers, nine (9) conference papers, four (4) posters. We have presented ReScuE and strengthened the partnerships among      academic institutions, industry, and government, reported the status of this      sponsored project, and/or acknowledged the generous sponsorship of the NSF      in over thirty-six (36) venues.
We      have successfully engaged around ten (10) Ph.D. students, eight      (8) master's students, twenty (20) undergraduate students, and one      (1) high school student during the supporting period. 
We      have provided professional training, lectures, seminars, guided      competition, research opportunities to more than ten (10) female      and underrepresented minority students.

We      have given lectures and training to ten (10) REU student      participants (2017) and twenty-four (24) GenCyber teacher      participants (2018).
At      OU, the System Administration Track of the BS program in Information      Technology has been designated as the National Centers of Academic      Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) in 2018. The sponsored project has      benefited most students of the IT major since 2018 at OU. The PI and other faculty have proposed a new B.S. program of cybersecurity in Fall 2021 and are ready to be reviewed by the School of Engineering in Spring 2022.
We      have led students to participate in cybersecurity-related challenges and      competitions, including the Oakland University Hackathon (Grizzhacks      2018), CyberTruck Challenge (2018 and 2021), the 2021 ISACA Detroit      Chapter 8th Annual Scholarship Competition(the 2nd place), and the 2021      MobilityForward AI Mini Challenge (the 1st place). The winners of both      competitions involve female students.
